newsitem.title: ISRAEL: PLO officials say Netanyahu-Arafat summit imminent.
newsitem.headline: PLO officials say Netanyahu-Arafat summit imminent.

text.p: PLO officials said Palestinian President Yasser Arafat would meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for the first time on Wednesday.
Israel Radio said a meeting could take place at 4.30 p.m. (1330 GMT).
Ahmed Abdel-Rahman, general secretary of the Palestinian Authority, told Reuters: "The meeting will take place soon."
Chief PLO negotiator Mahmoud Abbas, asked when a summit would be held, advised reporters: "Go to Erez," the Israeli-Gaza crossing point where a summit could take place.
But Arafat and a spokesman for Netanyahu said a meeting had yet to be set.
Asked when a meeting would take place, Arafat said: "It has not been decided yet."
Asked what was delaying the summit, he said: "Many issues. It is better not to mention it. But still there are many attempts."
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have been struggling over the past week to find a formula that would enable the two men to meet and for full-fledged peace talks to resume.
Netanyahu, elected in May on a pledge not to swap occupied Arab land for peace, had said originally he preferred not to meet Arafat but softened his position in recent days.
Palestinians have been pressing for a summit and resumed talks to tackle the issue of Israel's long-delayed troop redeployment from the West Bank town of Hebron.
